title: The Births Foretold
shortSummary: Luke chapter 1 introduces the miraculous births of John the Baptist and Jesus Christ, emphasizing God's sovereign plan and fulfillment of prophecy. Through angelic announcements and faithful responses, the chapter highlights themes of faith, divine intervention, and preparation for the Messiah's coming.
timeline: c. 6-4 BC - During the reign of Herod the Great, just before the birth of Jesus

keyCharacters.name: Zacharias
keyCharacters.description: A priest of the course of Abia who receives the angel Gabriel's message about his son John the Baptist; he initially doubts and is rendered mute until the prophecy is fulfilled.

keyCharacters.name: Elisabeth
keyCharacters.description: Wife of Zacharias, barren and advanced in years, who miraculously conceives John the Baptist as part of God's redemptive plan.

keyCharacters.name: Mary
keyCharacters.description: A virgin from Nazareth who receives the angel Gabriel's announcement that she will conceive Jesus by the Holy Spirit, responding in humble faith.

keyCharacters.name: Angel Gabriel
keyCharacters.description: The messenger of God who delivers the announcements to Zacharias and Mary, revealing God's plan for salvation.

keyCharacters.name: John the Baptist
keyCharacters.description: The son of Zacharias and Elisabeth, foretold to prepare the way for the Lord, filled with the Holy Spirit even before birth.

definitions.definition: One of the 24 priestly divisions established for temple service, indicating Zacharias' priestly lineage and role.
The altar in the temple where priests burned incense, symbolizing the prayers of the people ascending to God.
The third Person of the Trinity, active in empowering and sanctifying God's people; here, filling John even before birth.
The Jewish covenantal rite performed on the eighth day after birth, signifying inclusion in God's covenant people.
A poetic term for the coming of salvation and light from God, referring to Jesus as the dawn of a new era.

outline.heading: Introduction and Purpose of the Gospel
outline.description: Luke explains his intent to provide an orderly and accurate account of Jesus' life to Theophilus, assuring certainty in the teachings about Christ.

outline.heading: Announcement of John the Baptist’s Birth
outline.description: The angel Gabriel appears to Zacharias during temple service, announcing that his wife Elisabeth will bear a son named John, who will prepare the people for the Lord.

outline.heading: Announcement of Jesus’ Birth to Mary
outline.description: Gabriel visits Mary, a virgin, revealing she will conceive Jesus by the Holy Spirit, the Son of the Highest, fulfilling God's promise of salvation.

outline.heading: Mary Visits Elisabeth
outline.description: Mary visits Elisabeth, who is filled with the Holy Spirit and recognizes Mary as the mother of the Lord; Mary responds with a song of praise magnifying God's mercy and power.

outline.heading: Birth and Naming of John the Baptist
outline.description: Elisabeth gives birth to John; despite tradition, he is named John by divine instruction, and Zacharias' speech is restored, leading to widespread awe.

outline.heading: Zacharias’ Prophecy
outline.description: Filled with the Holy Spirit, Zacharias prophesies about God’s salvation through the coming Messiah and John’s role as His forerunner, ending with John’s growth and preparation.

application: Trust God’s promises even when circumstances seem impossible, as seen in Elisabeth and Mary’s faith.
Respond to God’s calling with humility and obedience, following Mary’s example of submission.
Recognize the power of prayer and God’s faithfulness in answering it, exemplified by Zacharias and Elisabeth.
Prepare your heart and life to receive Christ, just as John was prepared to prepare the way for the Lord.

keyVerses.text: For with God nothing shall be impossible.
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores the limitless power of God to accomplish His plans, encouraging faith in His promises.

keyVerses.text: And blessed is she that believed: for there shall be a performance of those things which were told her from the Lord.
keyVerses.significance: Highlights the blessing and assurance that comes through faith in God’s word and promises.

keyVerses.text: Blessed be the Lord God of Israel; for he hath visited and redeemed his people,
keyVerses.significance: Zacharias’ prophecy celebrates God’s redemptive work, affirming the fulfillment of His covenant promises through Christ.

keyVerses.text: And the child grew, and waxed strong in spirit, and was in the deserts till the day of his shewing unto Israel.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights John the Baptist’s spiritual preparation and dedication for his prophetic mission.
